organization.fullName: Iowa City Veterans Affairs Medical Center

identificationModule.officialTitle: Improving Post-discharge Antimicrobial Use: a Multicenter Stepped Wedge Trial Study

leadSponsor.name: Iowa City Veterans Affairs Medical Center

collaborators.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

descriptionModule.briefSummary: One in five hospitalized patients is prescribed an antimicrobial at the time of discharge, and a large proportion of these post-discharge antimicrobials are unnecessary. The investigators will evaluate a novel method for reviewing post-discharge antimicrobial prescriptions in real-time with the goal of improving antimicrobial selection and duration.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
Antimicrobial stewardship programs (ASPs) work to improve antibiotic prescribing within hospitals. ASPs often restrict their activities to inpatient antimicrobial-prescribing. However, at least 40% of all antimicrobial exposure associated with an acute-care hospital stay is prescribed at the time of hospital discharge (i.e., post-discharge). Post-discharge antimicrobials mediate clinical outcomes after discharge and may facilitate the spread of antimicrobial resistance.

Several studies have shown that post-discharge antimicrobial use is often inappropriate. For example, using national VA data, the investigators found that 61% of fluoroquinolone treatment days were prescribed at hospital discharge; manual chart reviews at 9 hospitals found that 40% of these post-discharge fluoroquinolone prescriptions were either unnecessary or sub-optimal. Other studies have found that 53-79% of all post-discharge antimicrobials are either unnecessary or sub-optimal.

Post-discharge antimicrobials are an important target for antimicrobial stewardship. However, inpatient stewardship metrics do not capture post-discharge antimicrobials and ASPs frequently do not evaluate these prescriptions. A 2016 VA survey found that less than 50% of hospitals routinely reviewed targeted antimicrobials at discharge. According to a 2016 survey in Michigan, only 17% of 48 hospitals had a process for reviewing outpatient antimicrobial orders at discharge.

It is unclear how inpatient stewardship resources can be effectively leveraged to improve post-discharge antimicrobial use. If the goal is to improve post-discharge antimicrobial use, a potentially effective strategy may be an audit-and-feedback process focused solely on prescriptions for patients who will soon be discharged. In this trial, the investigators will evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of such a process.

armGroups.label: Prospective audit-and-feedback at discharge
armGroups.description: When hospitals are in the intervention arm, they will perform the audit-and-feedback process focused on patients receiving antimicrobials who have an anticipated discharge.

armGroups.label: Standard of care
armGroups.description: When hospitals are in the control arm, they will not perform a stewardship process that focuses on hospital discharge.

interventions.name: Prospective audit-and-feedback
interventions.description: The stewardship team will review patients who are on antibiotics, have an uncomplicated infection, and are eligible to continue antibiotics after discharge. Any recommendations from the stewardship team about optimizing antibiotic therapy will be presented to the primary prescriber in real-time with the goal of improving antibiotic selection and duration at hospital discharge.

primaryOutcomes.description: The primary outcome will be post-discharge antimicrobial length of therapy (LOT) per 100 admissions. The investigators will calculate this by adding post-discharge LOT across all patients on the participating services and dividing by the number of patient-admissions discharged from those services during the study period.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Every 2-week-period through study completion (48 weeks total)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Inpatient antibiotic LOT will be calculated by adding inpatient LOT across all patients on the participating services and dividing by the number of patient-admissions discharged from those services during the study period.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Every two-week period through study completion (48 weeks total)

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Percentage of participants with hospital readmission
secondaryOutcomes.description: Hospital readmissions reflect the need for (re) admission to an acute-care bed at a participating facility for any indication within 30 days of the patient's discharge.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

--The local stewardship team agrees to implement the discharge stewardship intervention on at least one inpatient service or ward.

Exclusion Criteria:

--The hospital already has an audit-and-feedback process in place that focuses on antimicrobial prescribing at hospital discharge.
eligibilityModule.genderDescription: All patients on a participating inpatient service at the participating hospitals will be included, regardless of gender, race, or age.
